title: Evers tours flooded homes, says he hopes Trump will make a timely decision on FEMA aid
description: While visiting flooded homes in Milwaukee, Evers said he hasn't heard from FEMA since his call for aid Aug. 13, but hopes for a timely decision.
content:
Gov. Tony Evers said Thursday he wants federal recovery officials to act quickly to provide aid to areas of southeastern Wisconsin damaged by flood waters in recent days. As Evers toured flooded homes in the McGovern Park neighborhood on Aug. 14, he told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel he hasn't yet heard from FEMA directly but hopes the agency makes a timely decision on how to help the state. Evers formally requested FEMA assistance on Aug. 13.

"FEMA is going to come here and do an appraisal, but we also want to make sure they don't take their time, because we have people here that have lost their life, and they need help, he said. "Our goal is to get the president to make that decision ASAP."

As residents on N. 54th St. hauled their furniture, clothes and memories to the curb, Evers said Milwaukee's resilience is "unbelievable."

When asked whether he's concerned politics could enter President Donald Trump's decision-making about sending aid, Evers said he "better not."At one point, Trump suggested his partisan differences with California Gov. Gavin Newsom could affect his decision to deliver aid following deadly wildfires in the state. No such feud exists with Evers, and Trump has said he values Wisconsin, a state he won in 2016 and 2024 elections.

"There are plenty of people in Milwaukee who voted for him, so that would be a mistake," Evers said.

Milwaukee County is conducting ongoing damage assessments by sending personnel to each municipality and compiling reports from residents. Once the process is completed, the data is sent to FEMA and the agency decides whether to send aid.

County Executive David Crowley, Mayor Cavalier Johnson and members of the Wisconsin State Legislature have all called for FEMA support.

At a separate event in the Milwaukee area on Aug. 14, Lt. Gov. Sara Rodriguez, a Democratic candidate for governor, praised the efforts of Evers, Crowley and Johnson to get help — noting the state of emergency declaration and the request for federal assistance.

"Getting additional resources into the communities as quickly as possible I know is a priority," she said in an interview with the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.

Mary Spicuzza of the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel contributed to this report.

Sophia Tiedge can be reached at stiedge@gannett.com.

This article originally appeared on Milwaukee Journal Sentinel: Evers hoping for timely FEMA aid following historic flooding
summary: Gov. Tony Evers, who has toured flooded homes in southeastern Wisconsin, has expressed his desire for federal assistance from FEMA to be provided quickly due to flood damage. Evers has not yet received any direct response from FEMA regarding the aid, but hopes it will be made a timely decision. He also mentioned that he is not concerned that politics could influence President Donald Trump's decision-making about sending aid, despite previous suggestions that his partisan differences with California Gov. Gavin Newsom could impact his decision to aid after deadly wildfires in the state.
shortSummary: Gov. Tony Evers urges FEMA to act quickly to provide aid for flood-damaged southeastern Wisconsin, emphasizing the need for timely response and avoiding political considerations.
